transportation.taxi: Yellow taxi's are common but don't use meters. App rides are generally safer and prices are clearer.
transportation.buses: Cheap but oftern crowded, unpredictable, and not recommended for foreigners unfamilier with the area.
transportation.walking: Kabul is not a very pedestrian-friendly city. Sidewalks are uneven or missing and traffic can be chaotic. Avoid walking at night.
transportation.airport: Use official airport taxis or arrange a hotel pickup in advance. Avoid accepting rides from individuals inside or outside the terminals.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are the most common way for visitors to get around. The fares are cash and negotiated in advance similarily to Kabul.
transportation.buses: Local buses and operate without a route map.
transportation.walking: The center around the Blue Mosque and bazaar's is walkable but similar to Kabul the sidewalks and traffic is unpredictable.
transportation.airport: Taxis are the primary way to go between the airport and the city and many hotels offer aiport pickup.

popular attractions: Khwaja Abd Allah Ansari Shrine (Gazar Gah)

transportation.taxi: Taxis are widely available but make sure to agree on the fare before starting the trip.
transportation.buses: Does not have a city bus network but has intercity buses that are limited. When inside the city, minibuses are cheap but often crowded.
transportation.walking: Historical area around Herat are walkable by day and be mindful of surroundings at night.
transportation.airport: Taxis are the most reliable airport connection to and from airport. A formal public airport shuttle bus does not exist but many hotels are able to organize airport pickup and dropoff.

popular attractions: Miradouro da Lua (Viewpoint of the Moon)

transportation.taxi: Most taxis are yellow and blue and they do not always use meters so agree on a fare before starting the trip. Ride-hailing apps like Yango and Heetch are also available in Luanda.
transportation.buses: Shared minibuses are available but are often crowded and route information is confusing for foreigners. Not recommended for first-time visitors. Government buses cover different routes but are unpredictable and can be crowded.
transportation.walking: Certain areas of Luanda are walkable during the day such as the Marginal area along the coast and the city center. Avoid walking at night due to safety concerns.
transportation.airport: Services such as Yango, Heetch, an Allo are available in Luanda for transportation. Many hotels provide airport pickup and droppoff.

transportation.taxi: Agree on fare before starting the trip and they are easly found near hotels or central areas. Local ride-hailing apps may be available but are inconsistent.
transportation.buses: Shared minibuses are available but are often crowded and route information is confusing for foreigners. Not recommended for first-time visitors.
transportation.walking: The city center and markets are walkable but be cautious when walking at night.
transportation.airport: Ride to center of city is about 10-15 minutes and the most reliable transportation options would be taxis or prearranged hotel shuttles.

popular attractions: Cathedral of Our Lady of Pópulo
Art Deco Architecture in City Center

transportation.taxi: Blue and white shared taxis (Candongueiros) are the norm, but private taxis are safer for tourists. Always negotiate the fare beforehand.
transportation.buses: Intercity buses (Macon) are reliable for getting there, but within the city, minibuses are chaotic and routes are not clearly marked.
transportation.walking: The colonial center and beachfront promenade are pleasant and walkable during the day. Exercise caution after dark.
transportation.airport: Catumbela Airport serves the city. Taxis are the main way to reach the center, and arranging a transfer through your hotel is recommended.

transportation.taxi: Official yellow taxis are metered and generally reliable. Ride-hailing via WhatsApp (Speed Taxi, Merr Taxi) is common; Uber is not available. Airport trips have fixed rates (approx. 20-25 EUR).
transportation.buses: City 'Urban' buses are cheap (40 Lek) but often crowded during rush hours. The Rinas Express shuttle runs hourly between the city center and the airport (400 Lek).
transportation.walking: The city center is compact and very walkable, especially around Skanderbeg Square and the trendy Blloku district. Sidewalks in the center are wide and well-maintained.
transportation.airport: Tirana International Airport (TIA) is about 20-30 minutes by car. Hourly shuttle buses and 24/7 taxis are the primary connection methods.

transportation.taxi: Taxis gather near the Port and Friendship Park. They rarely use meters, so it is essential to negotiate and agree on the fare before entering.
transportation.buses: Public buses run frequently to Ksamil and Butrint (100-200 Lek). They are the most affordable option but get extremely crowded in summer. The main bus station is near the Synagogue ruins.
transportation.walking: The 'Xhiro' (evening walk) along the seaside promenade is a cultural staple. The city itself is built on a steep hill, making walking inland physically demanding.
transportation.airport: Sarande has no airport. Most visitors arrive via ferry from Corfu, Greece (30-70 mins) or by a 4-5 hour bus/car ride from Tirana.

popular attractions: Royal Villa of Durrës (King Zog's Villa)

transportation.taxi: Taxis are widely available at the port and along the beach. Always agree on a price beforehand or insist on the meter. Apps are less common than in Tirana.
transportation.buses: Durres is a major transport hub with connections to most Albanian cities. Local buses run along the coast to the southern beach areas (Golem/Plepa).
transportation.walking: The 'Volga' promenade and the historic town center are pedestrian-friendly. The main beach area stretches for kilometers and is best explored on foot.
transportation.airport: Located just 30-40 minutes from Tirana International Airport. A direct shuttle bus (Adis Travel) costs around 600 Lek, or taxis can be hired for ~25-30 EUR.

transportation.taxi: Ubiquitous and relatively affordable. Use the Hala app (via Careem) for easier booking. Taxis use meters and accept cards or cash.
transportation.buses: Extensive network connecting most parts of the city. Requires a Nol card for payment as cash is not accepted on board.
transportation.walking: Walkable in specific areas like Dubai Marina, Downtown, and Al Fahidi during cooler months (November to March). Not recommended during summer heat.
transportation.airport: Dubai International (DXB) is connected via the Metro Red Line. Taxis and ride-sharing (Uber/Careem) are available 24/7.

transportation.taxi: Silver taxis are plentiful and metered. Most drivers speak English. Use the 'Abu Dhabi Taxi' app or Careem.
transportation.buses: Modern air-conditioned buses cover the city and suburbs. Payment is made via the Hafilat smart card.
transportation.walking: The Corniche is a beautiful 8km stretch perfect for walking or cycling. Most other areas require vehicle transport.
transportation.airport: Zayed International Airport (AUH) is about 30 minutes from the city center. Airport buses (A1, A2) run 24/7.

popular attractions: Eye of the Emirates Ferris Wheel

transportation.taxi: Taxis are easily available and essential for getting around. They are metered and have a higher starting rate for trips into Dubai.
transportation.buses: The Mowasalat bus service covers the city well and also provides frequent intercity links to Dubai and Ajman.
transportation.walking: The Al Majaz and Al Qasba areas are very pedestrian-friendly and popular for evening strolls.
transportation.airport: Sharjah International Airport (SHJ) is the hub for Air Arabia. Taxis and public Mowasalat buses connect the airport to the city.

transportation.taxi: Radio Taxis are widely available and metered. Ride-hailing apps like Uber and Cabify are very popular and generally safer for tourists.
transportation.buses: The 'Colectivo' system is extensive and runs 24/7. You must have a SUBE card to pay; cash is not accepted.
transportation.walking: The city is known as the 'Paris of the South' and is highly walkable, especially in areas like Recoleta and Palermo. Use caution in Microcentro at night.
transportation.airport: Ezeiza (EZE) is the main international hub (45 mins away), while Aeroparque (AEP) is for domestic flights and located within the city limits.

transportation.taxi: Taxis and 'remises' (fixed-rate cars) are common. It is best to call one from a hotel or restaurant rather than hailing on the street.
transportation.buses: Local buses require a SUBE card. There are frequent routes connecting the city center to Llao Llao and the ski base.
transportation.walking: The town center is small and walkable, but most natural attractions require a car or bus due to the mountainous terrain.
transportation.airport: Teniente Luis Candelaria Airport (BRC) is about 15km from the city center. Public buses and shuttles are available.

transportation.taxi: Taxis are affordable and use meters. Remises are also a popular way to visit distant wineries for a flat daily or hourly fee.
transportation.buses: The city has a clean and efficient bus system and a light rail (Metrotranvía) that connects the center to southern suburbs.
transportation.walking: The city is designed with wide, tree-lined avenues and five main plazas, making the downtown area very pleasant for walking.
transportation.airport: Governor Francisco Gabrielli International Airport (MDZ) is a 15-20 minute drive from the city center.
